titleStmt.title: An entry from the Journals of Hensley Henson

sourceDesc.bibl: Edited from the manuscripts in the custody of Durham Cathedral Library.

p.hi: arrived. After five years in the East he has come back for 8 months leave at home. He has grown to be stout, & even more self–confident than he was as one of my incumbents in Hereford, but he has a frank, breezy manner, which (like charity) covers a multitude of sins.
writes that he had read a report of my Brighton Sermon in a Sussex paper:
"What you say about the homogenous culture of
time, & heterogeneous culture of ours, is the key to
our troubles: if I were an ordination candidate, it would make me
doubtful: & it is a question whether such preaching as his is now possible.
I never think you quite fair to Modernists
! What you criticize is a matter of temperament, & it is true that the critical, historical, legal temper is seldom mystical. But the orthodox temper is frequently not so."
